Questions: Why do people in the United States falsely claim that China is not a democracy?
Answers:
Primarily, because China fails to fulfil most of the requirements to be called a democracy. It does, however, fulfil many of the requirements to be called a dictatorship.

This being said, most people in the USA, and generally in the West, imagine that China is a much harsher dictatorship than it actually is. For instance, by Chinese law, elections to every assembly must have 120% of the candidates required to fill all seats; the choice is very limited, especially since they all have to be pre-approved by the CPC, but there is definitely an amount of real choice there. And while keeping political prisoners is of course wrong in every way imaginable, Amnesty International recognises some 1,500 political prisoners in China ‚Äì which is a lot, but you also have to realise that it corresponds to one in a million Chinese. This is not a sign of a society where every sign of dissent is ruthlessly persecuted, it is a sign of a society where you actually have to try quite hard before they start to bother about you; it is not a country where you have to watch your tongue every time you step outside, it‚Äôs a country where you have to think hard about what you publish in a newspaper with a big circulation.

There are degrees of dictatorship, just like there are degrees of democracy.

Questions: Are staged encounters by the police good or bad for democracy?
Answers:
Most people in India today appear to believe that police encounter is good because the Indian judiciary is quite slow and corrupt.

They argue that it takes decades for the courts to decide a case and often the criminals are set free due to lack of evidence, poor quality of investigation, complicated procedures and corruption in judiciary.

Hence, they compliment police when they provide instant justice by killing the alleged criminals.

However, it would be foolish to assume that people have more faith on police in India.

You can have this illusion only till you have to deal with police in real life.

If you have ever dealt police in India, you know how difficult it is to file even the First Information Report (FIR) in a police station.

The behaviour of the police official in general is extremely rude and they don‚Äôt think twice before abusing and even beating common people even in public view, though they have no power to do so under any law.

Imagine yourself to be the man on bike!

Now, if you unfortunately suffer a crime against yourself or your loved ones (murder, rape, extortion etc.) and the police fails to act in time according to law, what option you would have to get justice?

The only option which would be left to common men, when police fails, is take the law in their own hand and take the revenge of the crime.

It means that you have to kill the person whom you suspect to have committed murder, rape etc. against you or your family, and become a criminal yourself.

If that happens, the family member of that person would do likewise and the society would get into total chaos where the people would be taking revenge themselves and the streets will be filled street fights and gang wars.

When a large number of people will take law in their own hand, the police too would not be able to control them for long.

While police would protect a policemen when they commit encounters, they wont be protecting a common man if they do the same.

When the government and the government machinery (like police) itself loses trust in law and blatantly starts breaking the law in public view with impunity, they lose the moral authority to ask people to follow the law.

Morever, the same cop who kills criminals in encounter in broad day light when asked by politician, dedicate all their energies saving the heinous crimes are committed by the politicians and their relatives.

Judiciary may not be up to the mark, but still better than police since it is independent to politicians to a great extent.

A country without strong judiciary will be an autocracy and tyranny of majority.

India is today at the crossroads and Indians have to make a choice.

Do we wish to become a developed country like America, England or France by following the rule of law?, or
Do we wish to become the next Afghanistan and Syria where people have to fight their own battle to get justice in their country?

Their choice will decide the destiny of their country.

Questions: A question to those wishing to remain in the EU - what do you actually like about it?
Answers:
I am in my early 50s and the EU (or EEC as it was) has always been there, quietly doing its job.

To be honest I cannot think of a single thing that the EU has done that I would say was a detriment to my life.

It allowed me to travel easier to Germany when I decided I wanted to make a serious attempt to learn the language having become friends with some Germans in London.

Travelling there, no problem due to Freedom of Movement. When there, there was no requirement for me to have a study Visa (unlike my non-EU classmates) nor a requirement for me to have Health Insurance (unlike them).

When I stayed for a longer period I decided to register in Germany. Simple and I was treated just like any other German. For my non-EU friends I know the system is for more complex with Visas and Rights to Remain, etc. They have to go to the Office dealing with foreigners, while I went to the Office for Germans.

Politically I think the EU is about as democratic as you can get an international organisation to be. Not as democratic as a state, sure, but it isn‚Äôt a state and I don‚Äôt want it to become a state. Some do - fine, that is their right, but I don‚Äôt see the EU evolving into a United States of Europe for decades, if ever.

But, I did get an MEP who represented my political beliefs due to the PR system of voting, unlike in Westminster where that has never been the case. I wrote to him about some issue, he wrote back, he wrote to the Commission, they wrote back, we discussed it some more. OK, I didn‚Äôt achieve a major revolution in EU politics, but he accepted my point and thought it good and may indeed have raised it with fellow MEPs.

So now I live in Germany. At the moment I am an EU Citizen in Germany, able to function as though I was German without having become German. I liked that, I was proud of that. Brexit might force me to become German (and to give up my UK Citizenship) but that wasn‚Äôt my choice, but one that is being forced upon me.

The EU works hard to make things a simple as possible for EU Citizens. Healthcare, tax, registration, penisions, driving licences, marriage, work, study, retirement, renting, buying, traveling - the list goes on and on and Brexit has highlighted for us who do live abroad just how much we took for granted as we attempt to sort out the bureaucratic mess that is our post-Brexit future. I help with a group called British in Germany[1] (part of British in Europe[2]) and we are flooded with questions from concerned Brits as we try to work out what post-Brexit might mean for us.

I have worked in Germany, I have worked for a British company while in Germany, I have worked in the Polish office of a British company while being resident in Germany. All without any fuss. OK, there was one problem, the polish zloty. Another currency to deal with, to exchange (still have some left over, going to waste), while France, Holland, Austria allowed me to use exactly the same currency as in Germany, easy, free of charge (oh yes, the EU removed cross border charges on Euro bank accounts and of course I benefited from free roaming too so I could use my contactless bank card for small purchases too). And I could easily compare prices too.

I have bought goods from Germany while in the UK, I have bought UK goods while in Germany. Again all without fuss.

I am proud that the EU managed to expand and take in 8 former Communist states without them falling into dispute between themselves. I notice the less happy outcome for states which were unable to join.

In summary, I want to be part of this club, not outside it.
